Gene expression in neo-intimal hyperplasia K.H. Tay; Singapore/SG (gdrtkh@sgh.com.sg)Re-stenosis is a complex process and is still not fully elucidated. It occurs in response to vessel injury after virtually any form of manipulation of a blood vessel, including angioplasty, stent placement or bypass graft insertion and is the main limiting factor of long term success of these therapies. Neo-intimal hyperplasia (NIH) is a major component of re-stenosis and results from vascular smooth muscle cell migration and proliferation into the intima, followed by extracellular matrix formation. There has been extensive research to develop strategies to prevent re-stenosis. These include the use of radiation, anti-inflammatory, antiproliferation and anti-cancer drugs as well as gene therapy. Although there have been successful reports of using gene therapy to inhibit NIH in animal models, the genetics of NIH remain poorly understood. We have performed gene expression studies of NIH using the rat carotid artery re-stenosis model as well as in defunct human dialysis arteriovenous grafts using oligonucleotide microarray technology. Findings from these studies will be presented and potential applications of the genetic information gathered will be discussed. Learning Objectives: 1. To study the genetics of neo-intimal hyperplasia. 2. To discuss the applications of the genetic information in the management of vessel restenosis.

Cerebral perfusion in angioneogenesis and stroke T. Lim; Singapore/SG (tchoyoson_lim@nni.com.sg)Despite the importance of cerebral tissue perfusion in human health and disease, the available methods of assessment are limited. Conventional X-ray angiography and ultrasonography do not adequately assess tissue microvascular perfusion, and stable xenon computed tomography, single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) and positron emission tomography (PET) are disadvantaged by their lack of availability for widespread clinical use. Researchers in Singapore have developed and refined magnetic resonance (MR, including arterial spin labelling at 3 Tesla) and computed tomography (CT) techniques that hold promise as non-invasive methods to study functional cerebral perfusion. This presentation will focus on how these advanced techniques of physiological imaging are being developed and used in research and clinical practice in Singapore. It will include examples of ischemic perfusion in intracranial atherosclerotic occlusion, complex collateral perfusion and tumor vascularity. Physiological imaging using new CT and MR methods has the potential to be a quantitative method to stratify stroke risk and plan treatment in cerebral disease. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the role of CT and MR to measure functional cerebral tissue perfusion. 2. To comprehend the physiological parameters of cerebral blood flow, cerebral blood volume, and mean transit time in research and clinical practice. 3. To learn how functional cerebral perfusion methods can be used to examine patients with stroke and neoplasms.

Limb salvage with infrapopliteal angioplasty D. Wong; Singapore/SG (Daniel_Wong@ttsh.com.sg)Singapore has one of the highest prevalences of diabetes in the world. Critical Limb Ischemia (CLI) due to diabetic angiopathy is a common problem and almost invariably is a result of occlusive tibial arterial disease. With the application of coronary equipment and techniques to treat small vessel occlusions, limb salvage using endovascular techniques is now a viable treatment option. The aims of treatment have therefore evolved over recent years from primary major amputation to that of limb salvage using a combination of angioplasty, bypass surgery and medical treatment. Angioplasty, being less invasive and having few clinically significant sequelae in instances of failure, is now regarded as the first intervention of choice, rather than bypass surgery, whenever duplex ultrasound shows that arterial reconstruction is possible. In February 2005, a national registry was formed of all patients undergoing femoral-popliteal and infra-popliteal angioplasty for the purposes of limb salvage for critical limb ischemia. It is the intent of this paper to review the techniques used, short to medium clinical results and complications encountered using angioplasty for limb salvage in critical limb ischemia. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the role of interventional radiology in the treatment of critical limb ischemia. 2. To determine the short to medium efficacy of endoluminal techniques in terms of limb salvage for critical limb ischemia.

Imaging of articular cartilage has assumed increased importance because of the prevalence of cartilage injury and degeneration as well as the development of new surgical and pharmacologic techniques to treat damaged cartilage. This lecture will review relevant aspects of the structure and biochemistry of cartilage that are important for understanding imaging of cartilage and cartilage lesions, and describe optimal imaging techniques for its evaluation. Although plain radiography still has a role to play in advanced osteoarthritis, CT-arthrography and MR imaging are the most important techniques for preoperative evaluation of degenerative, traumatic and inflammatory cartilage lesions. The value of these techniques, including qualitative and quantitative post-processing techniques, will be discussed. Normal and pathologic imaging findings in cartilage and subchondral bone will be demonstrated and a grading system for assessment of cartilage lesions will be explained. Guidelines for optimal preoperative evaluation of cartilage will be proposed. Autologous osteochondral transplantation is an articular resurfacing technique in which cylinders of autologous bone with overlying hyaline cartilage are cored from non-weight-bearing areas of the knee (donor site) and transferred into similarly sized cored holes created within the cartilage defect to be treated (recipient site). It is a one-stage procedure performed in patients with a symptomatic fullthickness focal chondral or osteochondral defect between 1 and 2 cm. MR imaging as a non-invasive technique is the method of choice in the follow-up of patients with osteochondral autografts. MR should be performed with cartilage sensitive sequences such as fat-suppressed PD/T2-FSE or 3D GRE sequences, which provide good SNR and CNR. High spatial resolution is mandatory as it allows a better visualization of graft morphology, in particular for the evaluation of graft integration to the adjacent hyaline cartilage and bone. MR imaging also helps to evaluate the status of the subchondral bone, the thickness of the cartilage cover, the congruity of the articular surface as well as the status of the graft donor site. Osseous incorporation within 6-14 weeks, resolution of subchondral bone marrow edema and a persistent congruity of the articular surface at the repair site represent a normal development of the osteochondral autografts over time.A recent development of isotropic 3D sequences will further improve the visualization of osteochondral autografts from different planes and views including virtual arthroscopy. Recent advances in biochemical imaging such as contrastenhanced T1 mapping and diffusion-weighted imaging allow a functional analysis of the graft cartilage. Autologous chondrocyte implantation (ACI) is one of the comparatively new cartilage repair techniques. It is a two stage surgery process based on harvest of cartilage in a first session and subsequent chondrocyte culturing. In a second session, the defect is prepared by debridement and covered by e.g. a periosteal flap, and the chondrocyte suspension is injected into the defect.After an initial proliferative (6 weeks) and an transitional phase (6 months), the repair tissue undergoes remodelling (up to 3 years). The resulting repair tissue usually is a mixture of fibrous and cartilaginous components. Indications for the ACI procedure comprise cartilage defects of 3 to 12 cm² size. Good clinical results are described, predominantly for patients without major concomitant degenerative changes, for follow-up periods of 1 to 3, sometimes up to 9 years. The main complications are repair tissue hypertrophy and graft delamination, mostly occurring within the first 3 to 12 months and graft failure (fragmentation). According to available data, outcome seems to be better for the femoral condyles, followed by the patella in contrast to less promising results for the tibiae. The role of pre-OP MR imaging is in demonstrating defect, defect size and concomitant alterations contributing to establish the indication for ACI. Post-OP, to date, MR imaging has mainly been used to identify complications. Criteria for evaluation are: Thickness, integration, smoothness of surface of the graft and graft signal intensity. Persistent BMEP in the surroundings of the graft and underlying, newly developed cysts are potentially indicative of a problematic graft. Ferretti; Grenoble/FR (gferretti@chu-grenoble.fr) Radiation-induced lung injury is a frequent complication in the treatment of patients with malignancies of the lung, breast, or esophagus, lymphomas and mediastinal neoplasms. Thoracic changes are mainly related to the total dose, the radiation portals as well as the volume of irradiation. In the vast majority of cases, lung damage is limited to the field of irradiation. Lung injuries are divided into 3 pathologic phases: an exudative phase, an organizing or proliferative phase, and a chronic fibrotic phase. Radiation pneumonitis usually occurs 4-12 weeks after completion of radiation therapy. Fibrous changes take 6-24 months to evolve but usually remain stable after 2 years. The differential diagnosis includes radiation pneumonitis, local recurrence, lymphangitic spread of tumor, and infections. CT is more sensitive than chest X-ray in demonstrating radiation-induced changes. Radiation therapy may also induce tracheobronchial disorders, thymic calcification, pericarditis, vessel thrombosis, and parietal changes. In this presentation, we discuss and illustrate the characteristic radiologic features of radiation-induced thoracic diseases and association with radiation methods. Learning Objectives:1. To correlate the pathologic findings with the imaging appearance in radiation pneumonitis. 2. To show the most familiar presentations of radiation lung injury according to the delay between imaging and radiation injury. 3. To present the unusual complications associated with radiation therapy of the lung.

C. Drug-induced lung diseases C. Schaefer-Prokop; Amsterdam/NL (c.m.schaefer@amc.uva.nl)Many cytotoxic and non-cytotoxic drugs (e.g. antibiotics, anti-arrhythmic drugs, anti-rheumatic drugs, etc.) potentially induce lung disease. The prevalence of drug induced lung disease is likely to be considerably underestimated in clinical practice. Dependent on the pathological mechanism and course, acute and chronic lung diseases can be differentiated. Mostly, the diagnosis is rather difficult because clinical symptoms and morphologic findings are non-specific. They may simulate the findings seen in the lung after radiation, caused by an infection or mimic the pulmonary lesions of the underlying disease. Thus diagnosis must be multidisciplinary approach in which imaging play an important role. A prompt diagnosis is important, since continuation of the medication and thus of the lung injury may cause irreversible parenchymal damage with a fatal course at the worst. Cessation of the medication and appropriate therapy, however, mostly yield rapid improvement. Congenital lesions of the brain is a vast chapter, including: Congenital malformations, congenital infections, inborn errors of metabolism, brain destruction acquired in utero.Malformations are described by embryological timing and include neural tube defects, disorders of diverticulation (holoprosencephaly spectrum, cystic malformations of the posterior fossa), commissural agenesis, malformations of cortical development that can involve cellular multiplication, differentiation, migration and organization. Malformations also include extracerebral cysts and vascular malformations. Although brain malformations are characterized by specific anatomical features, MR imaging features can change across time along with brain maturational changes, especially in cases of malformation of cortical development, and in midline lipomas. The most common congenital infections are CMV and toxoplasmosis, resulting in malformations and destructive lesions. Neonatal herpes encephalitis is less frequent and highly destructive. Inborn errors of metabolism can be encountered in utero and in neonates, the most frequent seen being mitochondrial cytopathies that rarely display basal ganglia involvement (until the first year of life) compared to older children. Some metabolic disease are also known to give brain malformations (i.e. corpus callosum agenenis in pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency). Other metabolic disease are known to lead to brain damage similar to cerebral lesions of hypoxic-ischemic origin. Brain destruction acquired in utero of hypoxic origin can be encountered postnatally, especially in the neonatal period as stroke, necrosis. Acute events one to several days before birth also happen leading to brain damage, sometimes difficult to differentiate from cerebral damage that has taken place pernatally. The management of major GI bleeding is problematic. A proportion of patients require emergency surgery which is associated with high morbidity and mortality. Percutaneous embolotherapy, previously considered a high risk procedure, may provide an alternative treatment in this group of patients. We will assess the safety and efficacy of embolotherapy in the treatment of life threatening GI haemorrhage and to consider indications and techniques. Detection of a bleeding site correlates with haemodynamic stability at the time of angiography (r = 1 for a systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg). Embolotherapy for life threatening haemorrhage is an effective, relatively safe procedure with a low incidence of major complications. Its use depends on the identification of a focal bleeding point or vascular abnormality, which in turn depends on the haemodynamic stability of the patient at the time of angiography. Interventional radiology plays in increasing role in the treatment of trauma related hemorrhage. Catheter based embolization is currently a first choice option in many large trauma centers. To treat these patients it is essential to have an opti-mal infrastructure, preferably with focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) and CT options in the trauma room and full hemodynamic monitoring. Trauma embolization is to treat acute hemorrhage and or prevent late hemorrhage. Indications for treatment are increasing hematoma, parenchymal organ trauma, false aneurysms and contrast extravasation (CE). CE especially has a high predictive value for failure of conservative treatment. Patients with CE, even if they are stable should always be sent for angiography with subsequent embolization. Both safety and efficacy of trauma embolization have been proved to be very high in the larger studies. Embolization materials used are coils, gelfoam or in special circumstances a covered stent. The main goal of a screening test for cancer is to reduce the cancer-related deaths. The cancer must be common and curable and the screening test must detect it in a preclinical stage. Many other conditions are required, including a low falsepositive rate, a low false-negative rate, being harmless and low cost. Currently, mammography remains the only screening test that has been shown to improve survival from breast cancer. Standardized mammographic techniques, quality assurance procedures and standardized interpretation criteria are applied in several countries. However, debates continue regarding the effectiveness of detecting ductal carcinoma in situ, especially in older women. In addition, sensitivity of mammography decreases dramatically in dense breasts, less to 48%.Recently, several studies reported the value of whole breast ultrasound, subsequent to mammography in dense breasts. More than 90% of cancers detected only with ultrasound, were invasive carcinoma with an average size less than 1 cm and have been stage 0 or 1. The benefit from a screening test is optimal in these cases. However, none of these studies had the sonographic operator blinded to the mammogram, so ultrasound should not be considered as an independent screening tool. A protocol developed by the American College of Radiology Imaging Network studying screening breast ultrasound in high-risk women is in progress. Sonograms and mammograms will be independently read. Ultrasound requires no ionizing radiation, no breast discomfort but depends on the operator and equipment, so that standardized technique and interpretation criteria are required. The histological heterogeneity of breast cancer is well recognised. Pathologically however lesions are categorised according to the predominance of histological features. In Tabar's series of breast cancers, distribution of tumours showed a predominance of invasive ductal -no special type (65%). The remaining 35% of breast cancers comprise.-DCIS 10-15% -Invasive lobular 10-13% -Tubular 68% -Medullary 2% -Mucinous (colloid) 2% -Other 2%Common indications for cardiovascular MR in children with congenital heart disease include: Complex congenital heart disease in neonates and infants (for three-dimensional overview of cardiac and vascular anatomy), Cyanotic defects with diminutive pulmonary arteries (for assessment of pulmonary artery anatomy and aorto-pulmonary collaterals), Anomalies of the aorta (coarctation, interrupted arch), before and after intervention, Patients with right ventricular conduits (for assessment of pulmonary valve regurgitation, pulmonary artery stenosis and right ventricular function). C. Anomalies of the aortic arch system and pulmonary arteries I. Gassner; Innsbruck/AT (i.gassner@uibk.ac.at) Vascular rings (complete encirclement of the trachea and the esophagus) and slings (incomplete encirclement) may present with respiratory distress in the neonate or stridor and/or dysphagia in the older child. A wide variety of vascular rings and slings can occur, but the two groups of greatest clinical significance are those involving the aortic arch and the pulmonary artery sling. The aim of the lecture is to understand the embryology and pathology of these anomalies, to recognize their radiological presentations and to show how to exclude a vascular ring or sling reliably by ultrasound. When familiar with three important scans, one can definitely document normal anatomy and exclude malformations using sonographic examination only. First -document a left-sided aortic arch that gives rise to three main vessels and thus exclude a right aortic arch and a double aortic arch. Second -document a normal pulmonary artery bifurcation and thus exclude a pulmonary artery sling and anomalies of the proximal pulmonary arteries. Third -document either normal branching of the right innominate artery or three main vessels leaving the aortic arch with the first being the largest and thus exclude an aberrant right subclavian artery. This assessment won't take any longer than esophagography. CT or MR imaging should be reserved for imaging of a present anomaly. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the embryology and pathology of aortic arch and pulmonary artery anomalies. 2. To recognise the radiological presentations including plain chest X-ray of vascular rings as well as anomalies of the pulmonary arteries. 3. To get familiar with the ultrasound examination of these vascular anomalies. 4. To show the angiographic and MR imaging appearance of these anomalies. 5. To describe how to exclude in case of stridor a vascular ring or sling reliably by ultrasound. Early detection using mammography is the most effective diagnostic modality in breast cancer. Mammography has evolved from direct to digital X-ray in the past century; from chemicals to detectors. Moreover, the departments have had to change their configuration to face the new challenges. There are two methods to obtain mammography images: Indirect and direct. Indirect process includes all the methods using light as the intermediate step, to obtain the image: Screen-film, computed radiography and the indirect-conversion digital detector. Direct-conversion digital detectors use photoconductor amorphous selenium which absorbs X-ray photons and directly generates the signal, obtaining a digital image.The new scenario combines IT technologies and clinical skills. Daily work needs competences in networking, PACS and DICOM applications, RIS environment, CAD integration and pre and post-processing abilities to provide full advantages of digital imaging. These methods improve patient management, providing additional time for care during the examination. This is more evident in screening population. Radiographer's mechanical work is reduced technology as complexity increases, requiring ability in IT and an increase in their responsibility. Close work-up with the radiologist, understanding, evaluating and checking the images, is crucial in the diagnostic process. Take home points Digital mammography provides more information that can be processed by the human naked eye and represents a quantum leap in diagnostic imaging in breast diseases.The new technological environment is a reality today and radiographers should be ready for it. Emerging skills are necessary to face the new professional challenges. Processing of medical images has become a powerful tool for exploiting the full range of possibilities that the new imaging modalities offer, with ultimate goal to deliver high quality images to the observing physicians. The ability of imaging professionals to take advantage of this new digital environment is of crucial importance, since it has been shown that computerized processing of medical images essentially improves understanding, detection, and treatment of diseases. This course details the fundamental principles of digital image processing techniques (including image enhancement, and restoration), while explaining how imaging professionals can manipulate these techniques for desirable visualization results. The possibility of improving image interpretation by the combination of quantitative (using digital image analysis methods) and qualitative (observer evaluation) information will be discussed. Clinical applications, in which these methods have been introduced or might be useful, will be reported along with visual examples. Finally, the capability of computers to generate complete diagnoses as a second opinion tool will be investigated. Learning Objectives:1. To give a general understanding of the fundamentals of digital image processing techniques, including image enhancement, restoration and image analysis. 2. To explain why the ability to perform digital processing of radiographic images is a significant advantage. 3. To introduce the tools which are currently used in digital image processing. 4. To have a practical and visual understanding of various image processing methods. 5. To identify some clinical applications in which these methods might be useful.

A The potential benefit of multislice CT (MSCT) depends on the appropriate selection of patients. Benefits based on accurate detection or exclusion of disease are appropriate treatment decisions such as starting, continuing, discontinuing or even withholding specific treatment, or additional diagnostic procedures. Decisions on proper indications for MSCT are even more relevant considering the radiation risk factor. Because the accuracy of diagnostic tests is not perfect, the second type of risk is an erroneous treatment decision based on an erroneous test result. The third type of risk is direct complication of the test itself, for MSCT these are predominantly adverse effects related to contrast agents. The balance between benefits and risks of MSCT should be in favour of the benefits. Justification of MSCT deserves special attention since recent technical progress caused an increase of the number of MSCT examinations and an expansion of the clinical indications for MSCT. Differences between the volumes of imaging tests, including MSCT, in European countries is large. This reflects in differences in mortality attributable to diagnostic X-ray imaging and demonstrates that there is ample room for improving appropriate use of imaging, including MSCT. Appropriateness criteria such as those published by the American College of Radiologists and the Royal College of Radiologists in the U.K. serve as guidelines for the physician. Decision trees can be used to describe optimal patient flow through the diagnostic process. To resolve remaining problems further research, including meta-analysis and prospective studies, is required. As an introduction the technical basis of MSCT will be reviewed briefly. The most important component is the detector which typically allows simultaneous scanning of 4 to 64 slices in current MSCT scanners. In general, the geometric efficiency decreases and the collimation efficiency may increase as the detector pixel pitch becomes finer and the number of detector rows increases. The respective aspects are illustrated and discussed in detail. The X-ray source, the inherent and added filtration, the reconstruction algorithms can also influence dose efficiency; the respective factors will be reviewed. Patient dose levels in MSCT can be assessed quite accurately today based on tabulations or based on scanner-and patient-specific calculations. Typical values range between 1 to 20 mSv per examination. The parameters which affect patient dose are above all the scan volume, the chosen X-ray parameter settings, and to some degree the reconstruction algorithm. It is important to scan with parameters which allow maximum resolution, but to consider reconstructions with lower spatial resolution to limit pixel noise. The respective dependence of spatial resolution and image noise will be explained and demonstrated interactively. Low-contrast detectability and soft tissue differentiation, the prime objectives in most CT examinations, are affected by image noise and contrast characteristics. The influence of the spectrum on contrast and on low-contrast detectability will be explained and demonstrated.

Since the introduction of the first MDCT system, the technology has been continuously refined. Work on 248-row detectors and other systems are in progress, which may improve scan speed and/or resolution. Both, speed and resolution are important factors in pediatric imaging. However, a major disadvantage of MDCT scanning is the high radiation. Using unfavourable scanning parameters, exposure dose is substantially increased compared to single-slice scanning. Using low-dose technique in children and slim patients is an excellent method to reduce radiation exposure. Individual dose modulation and overlapping reconstructions provide a so-called "secondary raw-data set" which can be used for further image reconstructions. This technique includes low examination dose, low image noise, and the possibilities of multiplanar reconstruction, CT angiography and even virtual bronchoscopy. New software programs have been introduced, which enable tube current modulation according a predefined noise level along the zaxis. With this software, a dose reduction is possible in adults and children. If the dose reduction software is not available, it is still possible to reduce radiation dose based on the parameters given by the scanner software and depending on the clinical questions. Furthermore, there are several programs available, which help to estimate the doses or the CTDI of different imaging protocols in different scanners. However, the most sufficient way to protect the patient from radiation exposure is to use radiation-free techniques. The use of CT should be restricted to those who really need it. Learning Objectives: 1. To learn how to develop low-dose protocols for pediatric MDCT of the chest and the abdomen. 2. To understand how image noise affects the image quality of low-dose scans. 3. To understand which impact the field of view has on image resolution. 4. To learn how to improve image quality of low-dose scans using to post processing techniques. 5. To learn how to reconstruct secondary raw data sets replacing original raw data sets which need large storage capacity in order to enable further 3D reformations.14:00 In some patients this technique may also be the final examination. The addition of colour and pulsed Doppler sonography has contributed to assessing tumour involvement of vascular structures such as the portal and mesenteric system. However, a sonographic diagnosis of suspected pancreatic disease depends on patient-related factors and is not always straightforward. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) eliminates the problem of overlying bowel gas and allows for focussed high-resolution imaging. This technique is well suited to detect vascular invasion and EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy can further increase the diagnostic accuracy in pancreatic cancer. When compared to US the performance of computed tomography (CT) is less operator-and patient-dependent. The value of helical CT in the management of acute pancreatitis and pre-operative staging of pancreatic neoplasms is well established. Moreover, multislice helical CT using narrow collimation and thin slices, provides excellent spatial resolution and three-dimensional reconstructions showing all relevant anatomical information.Due to the introduction of (ultra)-fast MR sequences and the development of new tissue specific contrast agents, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may currently be as accurate as spiral CT for depicting inflammatory and neoplastic pancreatic disease. Moreover MR imaging has the advantage of allowing simultaneous investigation of the pancreatic duct, pancreatic parenchyma and peripancreatic vessels ("all-in-one"). In other words MR imaging can provide all information required to differentiate resectable from unresectable tumours. Exact pretherapeutical imaging is mandatory for optimal treatment of pancreatic malignancies. This course should provide information for staging and detecting of pancreatic disease. The focus will be on chronic inflammatory disease of the pancreas, which is sometimes difficult to differentiate from early pancreatic cancer and also on pancreatic tumors, that have very low attenuation difference to the normal pancreatic tissue. The course will also provide specific imaging features to identify these lesions on CT. Due to the development of treatment modalities based on thrombolysis, ischemic stroke is now accepted as a treatable medical emergency. In order to successfully begin therapy within the therapeutic window, neuroimaging can provide information based on computed tomography (CT) and/or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) protocols. Once haemorrhage has been excluded, it is important to assess the extent of potentially reversible and/or irreversible tissue damage: CT will show areas of less attenuation whereas MR imaging with diffusion weighted imaging will demonstrate the presence of cytotoxic edema; additional information about the hemodynamics of the ischemic region can be provided by both perfusion-CT and MR imaging techniques; these can help to define the presence of a potential penumbra or tissue at risk that constitutes the target for therapy. Additionally it is important also to assess the status of the intra and extra-cranial vasculature; this can be done by both angio-CT and angio-MR techniques; one should be able to assess the vasculature from the aortic arch up to the circle of Willis in order to demonstrate the presence or absence of stenotic and/or occlusive lesions, both proximally and distally. These protocols must be very fast so as to allow treatment to be started within the therapeutic window with safety; at the moment CT technology allows the fastest imaging with perfusion and angiographic data sets being acquirable in a few minutes. The same protocols need to be repeated in order to assess the effect of therapy. Although hemorrhagic strokes account for only 10-15% of all strokes, they have a very high mortality rate. The main two subcategories of hemorrhagic stroke include intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) and subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The most common imaging modalities for diagnosing and determining the cause of hemorrhagic stroke are CT, MR imaging and conventional cerebral angiography. CT remains the modality of choice in the acute setting of stroke to confirm or exclude a recent intracranial bleed, in addition to its advantages of availability and relatively easy interpretation. The current advances in multislice CT also allow accurate visualization of the intracranial vessels by CT-angiography and a rather efficient assessment of cerebral perfusion state in ischemic changes. Continuous progress in MR imaging made some authors suggest that susceptibility-MR imaging sequences are more sensitive than CT in diagnosing cerebral parenchymal hemorrhage, especially microbleeds. Diffusion MR imaging has been reported to show diffusion changes in recent hematomas. Perfusion MR imaging measurements have been used in the search for a perihemorrhagic penumbra. In cases of subarachnoid hemorrhage, the FLAIR sequence was reported to have a similar or even higher sensitivity than CT in the acute setting, becoming clearly superior in the subacute phase of SAH. The main limitations for MR imaging remain the technical and logistical considerations. Although being an invasive technique, conventional cerebral angiography is still the gold standard for imaging the intracranial vessels, determining flow characteristics, assessing aneurysms and arteriovenous malformations and performing intravascular interventions. The pericardium has an outer fibrous layer and an inner serous layer which surrounds the heart and contains approximately 10-20 mls of serous fluid called the pericardial fluid. The presence of this fluid reduces the friction between the beating heart and other tissues. The pericardial attachments maintain the heart in its correct position in the thoracic cavity despite respiratory motion and body posture. Acute pericarditis may be a result of a variety of causes, the most common of which is viral pericarditis which accounts for more than 10% of cases; however pericarditis can be due to bacteria, uraemia, neoplasms, hypothyroidism and myocardial infarction and many other clinical syndromes. Acute pericarditis has a characteristic presentation resulting in chest pain which is relieved by sitting forward and made worse by lying down. The ECG changes in acute pericarditis are also characteristic with 'saddle shaped' ST changes. A pericardial rub can also commonly be heard. Pericardial effusion is diagnosed by a number of modalities; however the most common modality is ultrasound. Acute pericarditis can result in cardiac tamponade which is a cardiac emergency. This is best diagnosed on ultrasound where the appearance is characteristic with a collapsing right heart appearance, and is treated by pericardial drainage. Chronic pericarditis can be caused by acute pericarditis. The most serious effect of chronic pericarditis is pericardial constriction which may be caused by tuberculosis, rheumatoid disease, sarcoidosis and trauma. Chronic pericarditis is better diagnosed by CT and MR imaging where the appearance of thickened pericardium is characteristic. Normal pericardium is seen on advanced computed tomographic images as a thin line of soft tissue density between mediastinal and subepicardial fat from the pars diaphragmatica till the superior junction line. Because of its anatomy and functional tasks it appears in front of the right heart a little bit thicker than along the left heart. Similar appearance is visualized by MR using various sequences. Pericarditis: Any thickening of the pericardium above 2-3 mm suggest the presence of an acute inflammatory process if smooth and chronic if irregular. Pericardial effusion: In case of enlargement of the pericardial space above 5 mm it is possible by analysis of the CT values and/or of the MR signal intensities to distinguish between solid, liquid, semi-liquid and haemorrhagic processes. Constrictive pericardial disease: The term "constrictive pericardial disease" is applied to inflammatory or non-inflammatory disorders that involve one or both layers of the pericardium and lead to constriction and compression of the underlying cardiac chambers. It is characterized by scarring and/or calcification of the peri-and/or epicardium which thereby looses its compliance and restricts the diastolic filling of the heart. Morphologic diagnostic patterns: -Thickening and/or calcification of the periepicardium -Narrowing of one or both ventricles -Enlargement of one or both atria -Narrowing of one or both atrio-ventricular grooves -Enlargement of the diameters of the inferior and superior caval veins. Functional diagnostic patterns:-Restrictive filling of one or both ventricles -Decreased flow in the caval and pulmonary veins -Paradoxical septal movement. Learning Objectives:1. To discuss the diagnostic possibilities of CT and MR.Cardiac imaging has greatly improved over recent years. This has led to increased utility of advanced imaging methods, such as MR imaging and multidetector row CT. Primary cardiac neoplasms are rare, accounting for less than 0.3% of autopsies. Of the primary benign tumors, myxoma, myoma and fibroma are the most common. The primary malignant tumors are mostly sarcoma (a few lymphomas will primarily affect the heart). Metastases to the heart are 30-fold more common, with melanoma, lung cancer, breast cancer and leukemia the most frequent causes. Echocardiography is by far the most common test to detect a cardiac tumor. Often, this is sufficient for further management. However, CT and MR imaging offer approaches that include better tissue characterization, evaluation of surrounding structures and even functional information. This presentation will focus on the various aspects of neoplastic (peri) cardiac diseases, including occurrence, imaging findings and pathological correlation. The preliminary study of a patient with internal carotid artery (ICA) stenosis is Doppler US. This technique enables the functional evaluation of the stenosis, thus allowing the determination of its hemodynamic significance. The morphologic assessment of the plaque, based on the gray scale evaluation, allows the identification of those symptomatic patients which, although they have normal peak systolic flow at US Doppler, have plaque with a high embolic risk. These patients are further evaluated using MR imaging with dedicated coils. All patients considered for endovascular treatment undergo an agio-MR imaging examination in order to confirm the morphologic results and to visualize the aortic arch to plan the procedure.In patients presenting with contraindications to MR imaging, these evaluations are performed with a VCT examination which also allows the use of post-processing programs like AVA and VR. The combined study of plaque morphology, using the gray scale method and MR imaging with dedicated coils, allows the selection of the most suitable protection device for each patient (block flow, filter device). Selective angiography is performed at the beginning and at the end of the procedure to visualize the intracranial vessels. The comparison of the images obtained may help in the identification of intraprocedural embolic events.In case of intraprocedural complications, a diffusion and a perfusion weighted MR imaging examination is performed to assess the presence of eventual ischemic lesions. Follow-up is performed with Doppler US, eventually integrated by agio-VCT examination in case of in-stent neointimal hyperplasia. Learning Objectives: 1. To discuss which imaging is needed for patient selection. Carotid artery stenting (CAS) is becoming accepted as a treatment option. The major concern expressed when comparing CAS with traditional carotid endarterectomy (CEA) has been the generation of embolic particles during CAS.There are a number of methods for the prevention of emboli, including technique, case selection, drug therapy, dedicated stent systems and cerebral protection devices.There are three basic philosophies of cerebral protection device. The first was balloon occlusion of the internal carotid artery. Subsequently internal carotid filters were developed, and more recently internal carotid artery blood flow stasis or reversal. Devices utilising all of these methods are available, with CE marks. The benefits and drawbacks will be discussed. Whichever device is selected for consideration, each adds a further step to the procedure. Evidence exists that indicates that the systems are all effective in vitro, and there is further evidence that such devices reduce the complications of CAS. However the introduction of these devices has occurred at the same time as other advances in CAS, it is not clear what are the relative contributions of each of these advances. In addition there are data which indicate that CAS, without the use of protection devices, carries an embolic risk profile similar to CEA. This raises the question as to whether they should always be used, and if they cannot should CAS not be attempted? Most practitioners routinely plan to use a cerebral protection device, but circumstances mitigating against their use does not necessarily mean that CAS should not be attempted. Magnetic rsonance agiography represents an attractive method for evaluating blood vessels without use of iodinated contrast material, ionizing radiation or catheterization. Current protocols rely on contrast-enhanced techniques almost exclusively. Although CEMRA adds a minor degree of invasiveness to the technique, the gadolinium-based contrast agents are not nephrotoxic, a substantial benefit over iodinated contrast agents and therefore also over CTA. With CE-MRA, spatial resolution remains suboptimal, however, published literature reports satisfactory accuracy compared to catheter angiography. Currently, virtually all medium-sized and large arteries can be evaluated with CE-MRA, more recently small arteries (e.g. spinal arteries and bronchial arteries) have been successfully imaged. The spatial limitation of poor head-foot coverage for the peripheral arteries has been overcome by moving-table technology (three overlapping coronal acquisitions for the peripheral arteries), more recently this has been extended to the whole body MRA (5 overlapping FOVs).With improved scanner speed, use of parallel imaging, superior coil technology and partial k-space sampling strategies both temporal resolution and spatial resolution can be markedly improved.Most of the artefacts and pitfalls are related to errors in technique and interpretation. A robust technique and strategies to minimize or eliminate errors will be presented.The role of new contrast agents, including blood pool agents will be discussed. This presentation will also discuss the role of non-contrast MRA (e.g. fresh blood and steady-state imaging) which has been the subject of renewed enthusiasm in recent years. Although offering benefit over CE methods, these approaches have not yet gained a foothold in clinical practice. A-392 C. Vascular sonography: New developments and directions T. Jargiello; Lublin/PL (tojarg@hotmail.com) Vascular Doppler US has improved its technical features and possible diagnostic applications through the last 5 years, until it became the most frequently used modality for vascular diagnosis in 1990s. Progress was achieved not only from an increased sensitivity of colour imaging techniques but also great improvement in B-mode scanning, particularly harmonic imaging and other software such as X-beam technique. In practice, this means that visualization of deeper placed vascular structures (for example in obese patients) is not impossible anymore. Introduction of US contrast agents was another forward step in Doppler diagnosis. Its use in evaluation of abdominal and peripheral vessels improved the diagnostic value of non-invasive Doppler examinations. Diagnostic specificity of celiac trunk, SMA and renal artery imaging rose respectively from 40% to 80%, from 60-100% and from 50 to 90%. In other peripheral vessels its role is not so distinctive but it is also helpful to assess problematic carotid, vertebral and lower limb vascular cases, especially in differential diagnosis between subtotal stenoses and occlusions. This is all to decrease the number of invasive or possibly harmful modalities and still have good diagnostic results. XXI century is a time for rapid development of interventional vascular procedures. Vascular ultrasound plays a major role in this. It is not only about non-invasive diagnosis, but mostly about cost-effective, reliable, and non-invasive follow-up assessment. Doppler US is now a basic technique for evaluation of carotid and peripheral stenting procedures and also a very helpful tool in primary diagnosis of AAA stentgrafting complications. Learning Objectives:1. To understand the uses of new ultrasound contrast agents in the evaluation of abdominal and peripheral vessels. Fetal ventriculomegaly is a frequent issue in prenatal diagnosis. It is defined as a transverse diameter of the ventricular atrium greater than 10 mm. It is called "mild" between 10 and 15 mm and "severe" above 15 mm. Sonography is the modality of choice for diagnosing ventriculomegaly. It can determine if ventriculomegaly is uni or bilateral, if the third ventricle is involved, and it can also look for extracerebral and intra-cerebral associated abnormalities: midline and/or posterior fossa abnormalities, gyration or migration abnormalities, haemorrhage and/or ischaemia. Indeed, the prognosis of ventriculomegaly largely depends on the presence of such anomalies. However, some of them (notably abnormalities of the white matter, heterotopias, some abnormalities of the posterior fossa) may be completely overlooked by sonography and MR may be very helpful in detecting such lesions. We will report the results of a large retrospective study about the contribution of US and MR in the diagnosis of abnormalities associated with ventriculomegaly.The prognosis of isolated mild ventriculomegaly is still debated and we will report the results of a prospective study concerning the postnatal follow-up of such ventriculomegaly. (2) were differentiated from enteric cysts (2). High anorectal malformations with (2) Fetal urinary tract malformations affect from 0.1 to 1% of all pregnancies, they are commonly detected by obstetrical sonography and account for 30% of all congenital anomalies. The spectrum of malformations is wide and the prognosis is significantly poorer in fetuses with bilateral anomalies and decreased amount of amniotic fluid. Imaging modalities are presently essential in fetal medicine. The routine follow-up of the fetuses is obtained by US which remains the predominant modality for evaluating disorders related to the fetus. The interest of the prenatal diagnosis is to optimise parents' counselling relative to the fetal prognosis and / or the postnatal follow-up of the newborn. Often, antenatal US is sufficient to establish the diagnosis of a urinary tract anomaly (renal dysplasia, renal duplication, hydronephrosis) but in some patients, the fetal anatomy may be difficult to analyse. We use MR imaging combined with sonography in the diagnosis of urinary tract anomalies in fetuses with equivocal or inconclusive sonographic data. This can be encountered: 1) in poor US conditions due to oligohydramnios which is commonly associated with urinary tract malformations (in cases of suspected bilateral renal agenesis or dysplasia); 2) in fetuses with huge urinary tract dilatation preventing proper visualization of the urinary tract anatomy; 3) in fetuses with renal masses; 4) in fetuses with complex genito-urinary tract malformation (cloacal malformation or bladder extrophy). MR imaging combined with US clarifies the diagnosis and helps in the establishment of the prognosis. Therefore, it entails a better management of the pregnancy and the newborn. Interventional rdiological procedures with which the radiographer is involved in the Department of Radiology at Odense University Hospital are varied. The character of the radiographer's job has developed and he now plays an important role in the treatment of patients. The radiographer's work during a neurointerventional radiology procedure start even before receiving the patient at the radiological unit, and the job is not finished until the patient returns to his unit. Sometimes the job even involves a follow-up days later.Radiologists and radiographers form a team in which the radiographer is a valued member because of his understanding of the procedures. The radiographer not only knows how to do the imaging but is also familiar with anatomy and the relevant radiological techniques. The radiographer is involved in the pre-and post-treatment of the patients and he is expected to be one step ahead of the radiologist all the time. He has to have a clear understanding of the clinical situation and to know about the advanced and changing technology within the field. The economy, the patient, the radiologist and the radiographer benefit equally from this teamwork. Learning Objectives: 1. To learn about a description of the interventional radiologic procedures at Odense University Hospital. 2. To give an overview of the radiographers work during a neurointerventional radiologic procedure. 3. To understand the benefits/advantages of the teamwork between the radiographer and the radiologist during a neurointerventional procedure.

back_matter.text: B. The value of cranial ultrasound in the neonate G. Cattell; Birmingham/UK (gillian@cattell.com)Ultrasound of the neonatal brain is a safe, simple and inexpensive examination in experienced hands that can be performed at the cot side. This makes it invaluable in the management of sick babies who cannot be moved and facilitates serial examinations. The information gained from the scans can be utilised to guide management as well as inform clinical decisions regarding intensive care. For example a minor intraventricular haemorrhage may require no intervention but post haemorrhagic ventriculomegaly may be amenable to intervention. In the term infant persisting increased echogenicity in the white matter may be diagnostic of an infarct or hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy depending on distribution, the gestation of the infant and the clinical presentation. The role of the sonographer is to report these findings to the clinical team and advise on follow-up and further imaging. Learning Objective: 1. To understand the role of cranial ultrasound in the initial screening assessment, management and prognosis in newborn premature and term infants.

A. Multiple clustered microcalcifications in a breast E. Azavedo; Stockholm/SE (edward.azavedo@karolinska.se)Calcifications may appear in breasts in different locations and in different forms. The ones that should not need any actions are for example those that are located in blood vessels, in fibroadenomas, in lobules, in fat necrosis etc. Differentiation of these do need experience in order to avoid intervention or follow-up. The lecture will give examples of topography of different types of calcifications that appear specially in multiple areas. Clusters of calcifications that appear in multifocal or multicentric ways can be within lobules in dense breasts, representing physiological calcium deposits, or represent residual products of tumor necrosis like in ductal carcinomas. Usually the shape, size and intensity of calcifications are good parameters to differentiate one from the other. Examples will be shown of clusters that need assessment including intervention. Aspects like interventional methods and modalities suitable for intervention will also be discussed in the lecture. The significance of tumor extent by analyzing the spread of microcalcifications is also essential to decide proper patient management. Knowledge of radiological tumour extent can change preferred surgery from breast conserving surgery to modified radical mastectomy and this will in the end prevent so called recurrences, that could in fact, be residual tumour due to insufficient surgery. Learning Objectives: 1. To learn to characterize multiple clusters of microcalcifications.

A-399 B. Multiple solid lesions in a breast K. Kinkel; Chêne-Bougeries/CH (karen.kinkel@grangettes.ch) At screening mammography, multiple, bilateral, partially circumscribed masses with similar appearance at mammography are classified as benign. Their interval cancer rate of 0.14% does not justify additional recall imaging. In patients younger than age 35 with palpable lesions and in patients with multiple abnormal mammographic findings undergoing recall or diagnostic imaging for BI-RAD 3, 4 or 5 lesions, grayscale ultrasound and color Doppler imaging are used to identify and confirm the solid nature of the lesion. Although color Doppler imaging can identify intratumoral vessels within a solid mass, this sign is not sensitive enough to be of practical use. For suspected solid lesions combined mammographic and sonographic characterization is mandatory to indicate tissue sampling. Frequent and reproducible sonographic criteria for benignity include circumscribed margin with round, oval or moderately lobulated shape (less than 4 lobulations) and a width to anterior-posterior ratio > 1.4. Posterior echo intensity appears less useful due to overlapping characteristics in benign and malignant lesions. To avoid biopsy of too many benign lesions, a follow-up program is recommended for lesions with a probability of cancer between 1-2% (BI-RAD 3, probably benign lesions). Increase in lesion size at follow-up examination, indicates biopsy. Sonographically guided core biopsy for two indeterminate or suspicious lesions in the same breast requires triangulation of lesion position and skin entrance of the needle to allow local anesthesia and biopsy to be performed through a single skin incision. For three or more indeterminate unilateral lesions, MR imaging of the breast might modify the biopsy strategy. Learning Objectives:1. To identify and discuss the solid nature of a lesion at ultrasound. 2. To discuss the role of different imaging modalities in lesion characterization. 3. To decide when and which lesion to biopsy according to patient and lesion characteristics. 4. To learn how to biopsy more than one lesion in a breast at ultrasound.

back_matter.text: C. How to manage high risk patients G. Forrai; Budapest/HU (forrai@ogyik.hu) High risk patient group consists of gene mutation carriers, risk family members and patients with: previous history of breast cancer, biopsy proven LCIS/ADH/ ALH, history of ionizing radiation. The oncologist and/or the patient are usually very aware of breast cancer, therefore "over-screening" is frequently indicated (too often repeated mammography, US and MR). The consequences are; continuous fear, hyperestimation of the personal probability of breast cancer and lack of patience in establishing the diagnosis. Overtreatment is often observed by sometimes multiple, immediate surgeries with benign histologic results. Mammography screening has to be started in this patient group at an earlier age and it must be completed by ultrasound if the breast structure is not completely involutional. Attention has also to be paid to multifocality, bilaterality, during pregnancy or breast feeding. MR imaging was proven to be very useful in the last year's studies. Specificity is much higher than in the normal patient group. MR imaging has the highest sensitivity among our diagnostic imaging tools. Most of these carcinomas are only detectable by MR imaging. The detection rate of cancer is higher; the cost is lower than by mammography screening of the normal patient group. Biopsy must be indicated more frequently in this group and requires consideration even in benign morphology lesions. Core biopsy or VCB are preferred methods over FNAC, because these patients are younger on average. Appropriate indications and contra-indications for the creation of iv access for acute and chronic hemodialysis will be presented. Prerequisites for the procedure will be mentioned. The audience will learn potential access sites for iv insertion of hemodialysis catheters. Advantages and disadvantages of different access sites will be discussed. Various types of acute and chronic hemodialysis catheters will be shown; strengths and weaknesses of the different designs will be demonstrated. The focus of the workshop will be on the practical presentation of the interventional radiological technique for hemodialysis catheter placement. The audience will learn in a step-by-step fashion the appropriate technique for safe and complication-free insertion of catheters. The combination of ultrasound guidance and fluoroscopy guidance for placement of central venous catheters will be underscored. Potential complications, preventive measures and interventional solutions for complications will be shown. Finally, aspects of catheter maintenance and rules for catheter changes will be presented. The workshop will focus on technical and practical aspects rather than on indepth discussion of results. At the end of the workshop, attendees will be able to initiate a central venous hemodialysis catheter placement programme at their own institution. Although good dialysis line insertion and management are essential for patients undergoing haemodialysis, arteriovenous fistulas are the preferred method for chronic haemodialysis in most patients. Each fistula has a finite lifespan. The venous side of the fistula responds to a high pressure circulation by neo-intimal hyperplasia which causes stenosis. These may cause problems during haemodialysis or can be asymptomatic. In either case, progression to fistula occlusion is usually inevitable. Fistula surveillance programmes and prompt radiological or surgical interventions directed at these stenoses can prolong the life of the fistula and avoid more complex treatments that are required when occlusion occurs. Many approaches to fistula angioplasty are used. In this workshop a relatively straightforward method will be described applicable to almost all patients in an out-patient setting. The relative merits of standard balloon, cutting balloon and surgical venous patch angioplasty will be described. With such a service, treatment of fistula occlusion should be less often required. The principles of treatment of these patients will also be discussed. Learning Objectives: 1. To be familiar with the methods of assessment of the failing graft and fistula. 2. To understand the principle of when to intervene in the failing graft and fistula. 3. To understand the principles equipment and technique of fistula and graft intervention including -when to perform PTA and stent placement -when to use cutting balloons -when to perform thrombolysis, thrombo-aspiration and mechanical thrombectomy.
