Building an electronic patient record system: Speech recognition

Building an electronic patient record system: Speech recognition J.H. Thrall; Boston, MA/US (jthrall@partners.org) Speech recognition systems translate spoken words into digital text. Commercial speech recognition systems are typically tailored for specific applications with respect to vocabulary and ancillary functions such as the ability to use pre-set macros and templates. For radiology, the systems are interfaced to radiology information systems to maintain the integrity of patient demographics and information about the radiological studies. The two most important advantages of using speech recognition are shortened cycle times for creating radiological reports and making them available for clinical use and significant cost reductions through reduced personnel requirements for transcription. The single biggest hurdle in implementing speech recognition is overcoming the perception on the part of some radiologists that speech recognition increases the time it takes them to accomplish the interpretation/reporting process. The keys to overcoming this issue are full education of system users, full use of macros and templates, comprehensive voice training and adequate system technical support for users. Vendors should also completely integrate speech recognition systems with RIS and PACS systems to reduce work process steps. Speech recognition reporting systems offer the rare opportunity of improving quality of care and quality of service while at the same time reducing cost. Departments of radiology that successfully implement this technology have significant quality and cost advantages compared with departments that do not. Learning Objectives: 1. To develop an understanding of how speech recognition works and how to incorporate speech recognition systems into the radiology interpretation workflow.2. To learn factors that are associated with successful implementation versus failed implementation of speech recognition systems. 3. To understand the potential positive operational impact associated with implementation of speech recognition dictation of radiology reports. Skeletal metastases are a common finding in cancer patients with a reported prevalence of 80% at autopsy. Skeletal metastases have a significant impact on the patient's outcome and on therapy options and so accurate tumour staging is mandatory. Most skeletal metastases stem from lung, prostate, breast, or renal cancer. Skeletal metastases occur primarily in bones with increased blood supply and in areas with red bone marrow. The clinical presentation of bone metastases is non specific and most skeletal metastases are incidental findings. The appearance of skeletal metastases is often manifold. Most commonly they present as osteolytic lesions, however, metastases with osteoblastic (sclerotic) or with mixed osteolytic/osteoblastic appearances may also be seen. Two main aspects have to be considered in diagnostic imaging:

1. Screening of patients with known primary tumours. Triphasic scintigraphy is still the imaging modality of choice for this purpose, however, whole-body MR imaging seems to be a potential alternative, because of its natural contrast on T1 weighted images when fatty bone marrow is replaced by tumor tissue. 2. Evaluation of incidentally found skeletal lesions, which is currently dominated by MR imaging. Recently new imaging techniques have been introduced such as multi-detector-CT, which opens new perspectives for preoperative staging and for reconstruction and implant surgery. Non-invasive techniques, such as diffusion weighted MR imaging which has the potential to exploit the microstructure of tumour tissue, and functional imaging, such as PET or PET-CT/MRI are now available. These techniques have potential for reliable tissue characterization, which is mandatory for planning and monitoring therapy. Detection of abdominal metastatic disease depends upon a number of factors including the location of metastatic spread, the imaging method used for detection, the technique used for evaluation, the histology of the metastatic lesion and factors altering the imaging characteristics of organs. The first part of this course will be focused on the liver, one of the organs most commonly involved in metastatic disease from a variety of cancers, in particular those of gastrointestinal tract, breast and lung. We will discuss the incidence of liver metastases, their prognostic significance and the role of imaging staging in the choice of therapeutic options. We will review the technical aspects and the advantages and drawbacks of ultrasonography, CT and MR imaging and common pitfalls associated with detecting hepatic metastatic disease. A rational approach of the use of ultrasound contrast agent and liver-specific MR contrast agents in the staging of liver metastases will be presented. We will also illustrate the imaging characteristics of liver metastases according to the histology of the lesion. In the second part we will discuss the imaging features of the most frequent extrahepatic abdominal metastases including peritoneal, spleen, pancreatic and gastrointestinal metastases. The growing role of metabolic imaging using FDG-PET in the staging of abdominal metastases will be discussed. Staging nodes is crucial for therapy and prognosis. Knowledge of the normal anatomy of nodes and the pathways of spread is important to recognize and to accurately localize them. This is extremely important for staging. In addition the imaging features of US, CT and MR imaging help differentiate benign from the malignant nodes which is very important. Conventional MR imaging and CT is using size and shape criteria, therefore, a node, especially when round with a diameter of 8 mm is suspicious to be malignant, but in this way many nodes will be missed by this these techniques. Also a cystic area is seen more often in malignant nodes. New techniques using "node specific" agents (PET tracers or USPIO MR particles) improve the characterization. Currently the threshold between benign and malignant nodes are not based on size and shape, but on morphology and signal. Thus 5 mm small nodes can reliably be recognized. New MR imaging techniques (like 3 T) and perhaps new PET-tracers will decrease this threshold even further. Chronic pelvic pain is one of the most common referral causes in gynaecology, it affects 15% of female patients between 18 and 50 years of age and represents 10-40% of consultations in gynaecologic practice. Nonetheless chronic pelvic pain remains a diagnostic puzzle in many cases given the multiplicity of possible causes. Causes are not only gynaecological, divided in acute and chronic pelvic pain, but also include digestive, muscular, urinary, neurological etc. We shall focus on chronic pelvic pain from gynaecological origin. Imaging modalities should not be undertaken before a thorough clinical examination, along with knowledge of clinical history, intensity, type, duration of symptoms, efficacy of previous treatments. A multidisciplinary approach, involving gynaecologists and imaging specialists, is compulsory in order to orientate examinations. As most of these patients are in the reproductive age, imaging should only consider non irradiating modalities: US and MR imaging. Assessment should always begin with US, and be completed with MR imaging when US is inconclusive or normal. Gynaecologic causes are dominated by endometriosis, adenomyosis, myomas, pelvic congestion syndrome, pelvic floor dysfunction, uterine malposition, dysovulation, chronic adnexal torsion, chronic infections. Specifically, identification and extent determination of endometriosis requires specially focused examinations in order to detect small deep lesions. Learning Objectives: 1. To review the common and less common causes of female pelvic pain. 2. To propose a logical step by step diagnostic assessment, given the frequency of the various causes and the clinical varieties of pain. 3. To review the diagnostic input of imaging modalities (clinical examination, ultrasound, MR imaging, CT and laparoscopy).

Uterine arteries embolization in female pelvic pain: Uterine myomas R.D. Garcia-Mónaco; Buenos Aires/AR (rgmonaco@fibertel.com.ar)Embolization of uterine myomata has largely developed in the last decade. The rationale of treatment is catheterization of the uterine arteries providing a safety route for fibroid embolization and infarction, that is usually followed by relief of a patient's symptoms. Uterine myomata are very common in young females, but treatment should only be directed to symptomatic patients. The commonest indications of embolization are heavy menstrual bleeding and bulk symptoms. Pelvic pain as an isolated symptom is uncommon, and in such a case sudden fibroid infarction or torsion of a pedunculated myomata should be suspected. Embolization should not be performed in asymptomatic patients or when bleeding is associated with small intramural fibroids that do not distort the endometrial cavity. Submucosal fibroids are best treated by hysteroscopic resection, and fibroids causing fertility problems usually referred for myomectomy. Hysterectomy is usually preferred for massively enlarged uterus or when there is a uterine mass that appears to be a sarcoma. Pre procedure gynecologic evaluation is mandatory, not just to confirm that symptoms are caused by the fibroids but to rule out malignancy or other infectious or concomitant diseases. The interventional radiologist is recommended to discuss with the patient the details of the procedure and potential complications as well as other therapeutic alternatives. Post procedural care includes pain control by NSAID or even morphine derivates. Clinical follow-up is essential not only to asses the clinical result but to rule out or obtain early diagnosis of delayed complications such as infection, expulsion of fibroids or others.

Uterine arteries embolization in female pelvic pain: Adenomyosis J.-P. Pelage; Boulogne/FR (jean-pierre.pelage@apr.ap-hop-paris.fr)Adenomyosis is a benign uterine disease characterized by ectopic endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium. Adenomyosis is associated with myometrial hypertrophy and may be either focal or diffuse. This common gynecologic condition which affects premenopausal women is associated with clinical manifestations similar to those of uterine fibroids. Although adenomyosis and uterine fibroids can have the same presenting symptoms including infertility, abnormal uterine bleeding, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain, their treatment can differ. Traditionally, adenomyosis requires hysterectomy because of poor results of hormonal treatment or endometrial ablation. The use of uterine artery embolization to treat fibroid-related pain is well-accepted. In these studies, uterine fibroid embolization contributed to clinical improvement in approximately 80-90% of women and resulted in significant fibroid and uterine shrinkage. In centers where uterine fibroid embolization has been performed without a screening magnetic resonance imaging, failures has been attributed to the presence of undiagnosed adenomyosis. However, other centers have reported encouraging short and mid-term clinical results in women with adenomyosis-related pain. Intense postprocedure pain is usually observed after embolization in most patients with adenomyosis probably because of myometrial ischemia induced by the technique of embolization used. As initially reported with uterine fibroid embolization, the technique of embolization consists of complete occlusion of both uterine arteries to effect stasis or near stasis. Initial control of pain and bleeding symptoms can be expected after uterine artery embolization for adenomyosis. However, long-term results seem disappointing. Embolization should only be offered to women with realistic expectations regarding the duration of clinical improvement. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the indications for uterine artery embolization for adenomyosis with special emphasis on pain. 2. To discuss the different embolization strategies. 3. To review the literature with available evidence with respect to published data on adenomyosis treated with uterine artery embolization.

Pelvic congestion syndrome: Diagnosis and treatment L.S. Machan; Vancouver, BC/CA (lmachan@vanhosp.bc.ca)There are two distinct patient groups to whom ovarian vein embolization can be applied. 1. Chronic pelvic pain. Pelvic congestion syndrome refers to chronic pelvic pain caused by pelvic varicose veins, almost always from reverse flow in the ovarian vein. Chronic pelvic pain is defined as "pelvic pain that is present for at least 6 months". It is one of the most frustrating and common problems encountered in gynecology. Laparoscopy is essential to exclude other causes of pelvic pain. Ovarian venography is the most frequent means of diagnosis, although some rely on duplex ultrasound. Treatment options include embolization, surgery, or hysterectomy. All means of treatment for chronic pelvic pain have at least a 20% failure rate. 2. A second patient group presents with varicose veins of the perineum or legs. This indication has become more important as endovascular treatments for lower limb varicosities have increased. Although these patients require less complicated clinical management, specific knowledge or shared clinical care with an expert in lower extremity venous disease is essential for good clinical results. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the clinical significance of ovarian vein reflux in patients with chronic pelvic pain or lower extremity varicose veins. 2. To describe the findings of pelvic congestion syndrome on cross sectional imaging and venography. 3. To understand the role of interventional radiology in the diagnosis and treatment of pelvic congestion syndrome.

Virtual autopsy (Introduction) P. Vock; Berne/CH (peter.vock@insel.ch)The potential of postmortem sectional imaging has not been well recognised by most radiologists working in a clinical environment. Autopsy rates have dropped during the last two decades, and religious arguments nearly suppress autopsy in several cultural areas. Postmortem imaging offers two major advantages over conventional autopsy. First, based on the non-destructive examination, there is usually no objection by the relatives, and three-dimensional topography is maintained in contrast to an open dissection; in complex trauma, imaging may be superior to autopsy in demonstrating the range of skeletal injuries. Second, the situation is frozen and easily distributed to all persons involved, avoiding the natural postmortem degradation of tissue. Forensic and non-forensic applications will be reviewed in this session. Learning Objectives: 1. To show the great potential of post mortem diagnostic CT and MR imaging. 2. To discuss major differences between intra vital and post mortem imaging and to inform the radiologists about successful approaches to virtual autopsy. 3. To work out the specific advantages and disadvantages of real and virtual autopsy respectively.

Postmortem CT and MR imaging in forensic medicine M. Thali; Berne/CH (Michael.Thali@irm.unibe.ch)The aim of the VIRTOPSY (virtual autopsy) project (www.virtopsy.com) is utilizing 3D body-surface documentation and minimal-invasive, image-guided virtual autopsy utilizing optical and radiological scanning to advance low-tech documentation and autopsy procedures in a world of high-tech medicine in order to improve scientific value, and to increase significance and quality in the forensic field. The Institute of Forensic Medicine and the Institute of Radiology, University of Berne are, in collaboration with a well selected national and international research team, evaluating and validating several cutting-edge technologies such as 3D optical and photogrammetric surface scanning, computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy, micro-CT, micro-MR, post-mortem biopsy, and post-mortem angiography. Using these imaging methods it could be demonstrated that a real, full 3D data based individual documentation of body surface and internal structures is possible in a non-invasive and non-destructive manner. Using the data merging/fusing and animation possibilities, it is possible to answer reconstructive questions of the dynamic development of patterned injuries (morphologic imprints) and to evaluate the possibility, that they are matchable or linkable to suspected injury-causing instruments. Real 3D data based documentation opens a new horizon for scientific reconstruction and animation by bringing added value and a real quality improvement in forensic science. The paper will give an overview of the Virtopsy actual and future change process in forensic medicine. Learning Objectives: 1. To give an overview of imaging techniques in forensic science, such as 3D optical body surface scanning, CT, MR imaging, micro-CT and micro-MR. 2. To show current forensic reconstruction based upon merged real data from body surface scans and images of internal organs. 3. To outline future developments towards minimally invasive autopsy for the court system.

Virtual autopsy and postprocessing of data A. Persson; Linköping/SE (anders.persson@cmiv.liu.se)A thorough understanding of underlying mechanisms and optimal technique is essential to fully exploit the diagnostic potential of new volume acquisition modalities. To obtain satisfactory 3D images for a virtual autopsy from computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), several key parameters need to be optimized and new technologies need to be developed. It is important to understand the principles of postmortem CT and MR imaging to utilize the new capabilities and to be aware of its limitations. The field of visualization provides methods facilitating visual presentation of postmortem data that are difficult to immediately grasp such as large volume datasets. It includes software making the visual inspection of medical image data easier, faster or more efficient. Once a high quality postmortal dataset has been acquired, the rendering technique is the most important technical determinant of 3D image quality. The rendering technique is the computer algorithm used to transform the 3D datasets, available in the workstation or PACS, into 2D images, visible on a monitor or film. If this is properly performed, the rendered image may give the viewer a good understanding of the underlying 3D post mortal anatomy and the cause of death. The advantages and disadvantages of different rendering techniques of postmortal datasets will be discussed. We will also present some of the technical aspects of volume rendering such as novel data compression based on medical domain knowledge and high quality level of detail rendering. Also interaction techniques tailored for post-mortem procedures will be discussed.

Postmortem dynamic angiography using a modified heart-lung machine S. Grabherr; Berne/CH (silke.grabherr@virtopsy.com)Purpose: To perform a postmortem dynamic angiography that demonstrates the whole vascular system (arterial and venous) even several days after death.

In first investigations cadavers of dogs and cats were perfused with diesel oil via a peristaltic pump. The lipophilic contrast agent Lipiodol ultrafluide® was then injected and angiography performed. To transform this technique for the use on human body the peristaltic pump was replaced by a modified heart-lung machine. The efficiency of perfusion was evaluated in the chick chorioallantoic-membrane.Results: Vessels could be demonstrated up to the level of the smaller supplying and draining vessels. Hence, both the arterial and the venous side of the vascular system could be distinguished. The chorioallantoic membrane assay revealed that diesel oil enters microvessels up to 50 µm in diameter. It does not penetrate the capillary network.

After establishing a post-mortem circulation by diesel oil-perfusion, angiography can be performed by injection of Lipiodol. The use of a modified heart-lung machine allows a pressure-controlled perfusion and dynamic angiography with arterial and venous phase. The resolution of the images obtained up to three days after death is comparable to that achieved in clinical angiography. Learning Objectives: 1. To outline postmortem angiographic diagnostic techniques. 2. To discuss limitations of previous postmortem angiographic techniques. 3. To demonstrate postmortem angiography of the whole vascular system using a modified heart-lung-machine.

Virtual autopsy: Adjunct to or replacement of autopsy? P. MacMahon; Dublin/IEThe decline in usage of the traditional autopsy after hospital or community deaths has been recognised for some time. The probable reason behind this decline is a fear of disfigurement of the remains of the deceased. Additionally, certain groups have religious and cultural objections to traditional autopsy. In the event of autopsy refusal, whole body magnetic resonance imaging has been proposed as an alternative autopsy method. MR can be used as a non-invasive autopsy technique or as an adjunct to a minimally invasive autopsy. A major disadvantage of MR autopsy is that no tissue samples are obtained for cytogenic or histological analyses, however selective needle autopsies may compensate for this. A few small studies have evaluated the accuracy of MR autopsy in adults and neonates.In adults the main diagnostic difficulties were in assessing for coronary artery lesions, differentiating postmortem from premortem clot and evaluating the significance of postmortem pulmonary infiltrates. In neonates difficulty was found in examining for complex cardiac malformations and small anomalous anatomical connections. MR autopsy's advantages over conventional imaging modalities are that it is whole body and that it offers excellent tissue contrast by utilising different MR sequences, especially in evaluating intracranial or CNS pathology. With increased operator experience it is envisaged that diagnostic accuracy would increase. Full postmortem dissection remains the gold standard. In situations where relatives refuse a traditional postmortem, and if resources allow it, MR autopsy may be offered as a less invasive method of establishing the cause of death. Major advances in cardiac imaging have resulted in better diagnostic as well as prognostic workup of patients with coronary artery disease (CAD). Most recently multimodality imaging procedures have been introduced to combine high resolution characterization of cardiac morphology with functional parameters such as myocardial perfusion, metabolism and molecular signals. The combination of multidetector CT with PET or SPECT imaging allows the comprehensive evaluation of patients with cardiac disease. Early detection of coronary artery disease involves the identification of coronary calcification as well as the documentation of endothelial dysfunction. SPECT-CT allows the correlation of coronary calcification (CAL) with regional myocardial perfusion reserve. Future clinical investigations have to prove the incremental prognostic value by combining both modalities. In patients with advanced CAD the combination of noninvasive coronary angiography by CTA with SPECT and PET may identify functional abnormalities in relation to coronary artery stenosis. The simultaneous co-registration of various imaging parameters provides guidelines for regional therapy and for monitoring of interventions. Especially in patients with CAD and impaired left ventricular function the combination of CTA and PET may provide specific markers for the extent of viable tissue and helps to define the appropriate revascularization therapy. Future studies evaluating the cost efficacy of hybrid instrumentation is necessary in order to justify their use in clinical routine. However, with the advent of molecular imaging, the co-registration of molecular signals with morphologic characterization of cardiac and vascular tissue is extremely attractive for clinical translational research. Learning Objectives: 1. To discuss hybrid instrumentation. 2. To review the correlation of structural and biologic imaging. 3. To discuss potential clinical applications in cardiology.

Cardiac MRI E. Di Cesare; L'Aquila/IT Nowadays cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) plays a significant role in the clinical setting of many cardiac pathological conditions. The use of CMR is well established in the identification of the cardiomyopathies, cardiac tumors and thrombus as well as pericardial disease and congenital cardiomyopathies.More recently the possibilities of combining morpho-functional information and perfusion studies has proven to be of growing interest in ischemic disease. Ischemia is considered as an anemia of the heart in which there is a mismatch between oxygen supply and oxygen need.The clinical presentations of myocardial ischemia are 1. chronic stable angina, 2. unstable angina, 3. variant angina, myocardial infarct. In all these conditions Myocardial oxygen supply is inadequate compared to myocardial oxygen needs. In chronic stable angina, the symptoms appear during stress and MR imaging is adequate to evaluate perfusion or function before the angina and similarly left ventricular dysfunction and perfusion defects appear before the increase of cardiac enzymes in infarction. CMR is able in fact to delineate regional and functional dysfunction better than any other techniques. Echocardiography is limited in the evaluation of epicardial borders and apical region. Moreover with MR imaging, it is possible perform perfusion studies able to analyze the status of the micro circulation at rest and during stress by means of rapid sequences susceptible to gadolinium. Perfusion can be analyzed at first passage but also the persistence of the gadolinium in to the myocardium 15-20 minutes later that means necrotic or fibrotic evolution at this region.

Whole body imaging in oncology with PET/CT T.F. Hany; Zürich/CH (thomas.hany@usz.ch)Over the last five years, PET-CT has grown because the PET portion shows information which is very different from that obtainable with other imaging modalities. However, the paucity of anatomic landmarks in PET makes a consistent "hardware-fusion" to anatomic cross-sectional data extremely useful. All clinical experience points to a single direction: addition of CT to PET improves foremost specificity, but also sensitivity and adding PET to CT adds sensitivity and specificity in tumor imaging: thus PET-CT is a more accurate test than either of its components and probably also than side-by-side viewing of both modalities. The synergistic advantage of adding CT is that the attenuation correction needed for PET data can also be derived from the CT data, an advantage not obtainable by integrating PET and MR imaging. This makes PET-CT 25-30% faster than PET alone using standard attenuation methods, leading to higher patient throughput and a more comfortable examination for patients typically lasting 30 minutes or less.Recently published results will be demonstrated and discussed in this lecture. FDG-PET-CT appears to provide relevant information on the staging and therapy monitoring of many tumors, such as bronchial carcinoma, mesothelioma, colorectal cancer, lymphoma, melanoma and many others with the notable exception of prostatic cancer. For this cancer, choline derivatives may possibly become useful radiopharmaceuticals. The published literature on the applications of FDG-PET-CT in oncology is still limited but several well designed studies have demonstrate the benefits of PET-CT. Purpose: Recently, multi-channel whole body MR imaging (WB MR imaging) systems have been introduced, which allow for coverage of the whole body and uncompromised image quality. Imaging protocols for the diagnostic work-up of oncologic patients and the diagnostic potential of this approach will be discussed. Methods: Parallel imaging techniques allow for substantial reduction of acquisition times and high spatial resolution. T1-weighted and STIR sequences proved sensitive and specific for assessment of tumor spread in the skeletal system and within soft tissues. With breath held single shot sequences, such as HASTE, high resolution imaging of the lung could be obtained. Static and dynamic contrastenhanced imaging is required for the examination of parenchymal organs and brain. Results: While PET/CT was superior in the detection of lymph node metastases, WB MR imaging was superior in the detection of skeletal, liver and brain metastases. Pulmonary metastases could be detected when they had a size of 7 mm and more. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) encompasses a broad spectrum of airway and lung diseases ranging from chronic bronchitis to end-stage emphysema. The main risk factor for developing COPD is smoking. Obstruction can be caused by bronchial wall thickening, hypersecretion of mucus, increased collapsibility of bronchial walls, and alveolar destruction with loss of elasticity. Besides obstruction detected by a loss of the forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and increased airway resistance, hyperinflation with increased total lung capacity and residual volume are hallmarks of the disease. Chest radiography will only pick up advanced disease when bronchial wall thickening becomes visible as tram lines or hyperinflation by hyperlucent lungs with vascular pruning, an enlarged retrosternal space and flattening or even inversion of the diaphragm. CT is capable of demonstrating early changes such as bronchial dilatation, bronchial wall thickening and low attenuation areas representing emphysema. Segmentation of the lung and the emphysematous areas can be easily done by thresholding, and the relative volume occupied by emphysema can be calculated. Assessment of expiratory scans is worthwhile to detect air trapping as a functional sign of COPD and to separate reversible hyperinflation from fixed emphysematous destruction. Collapsibility of airways can be best visualized by dynamic cine CT or MR imaging. It is difficult to visualize airways and emphysema directly by MR imaging. However, MR imaging is can provide functional imaging, ventilation MR imaging, e.g. using hyperpolarized 3 He, MR angiography and perfusion MR imaging, to depict ventilation defects and the effects of hypoxic vasoconstriction. Learning Objectives: 1. To correlate the pathology of COPD and emphysema with the findings at projection radiography and CT. 2. To learn about the post-processing of CT images to quantitatively describe the severity of COPD and emphysema. 3. To discuss the impact of functional imaging using CT and MR imaging.

B. Asthma and allergic lung disease P.-Y. Brillet; Bobigny/FR (pybrillet@yahoo.fr) Asthma and allergic lung diseases are characterized by chronic inflammation of the airways, with additional alveolitis and granulomas in allergic lung diseases. These diseases are influenced by many factors, including genetic susceptibility and exposure to environmental allergens. Their increasing prevalence and the new opportunities with computed tomography (CT) have led to a higher demand on imaging examinations for the diagnosis of disease and for the follow-up under treatment. In this review, we will highlight the key imaging appearance in asthma and associated conditions: foremost allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis and Churg-Stauss syndrome, and extrinsic allergic alveolitis, also known as hypersensitivity pneumonitis. In asthma, airway hyperactivity and chronic inflammation lead to airway remodelling, which is responsible for bronchial wall thickening and pulmonary obstruction. CT is ideally suited for the noninvasive investigation of airway structure and function by quantification of bronchial dimensions (lumen and wall areas), measurement of the lung attenuation and evaluation of air trapping. Results of the main clinical studies will be discussed herein. Learning Objectives:1. To know the radiographic and CT abnormalities observed in asthma and associated conditions. 2. To know the radiographic and CT abnormalities observed in allergic lung disease. 3. To be familiar with the use of CT for quantification of airways dimensions and air trapping in the assessment of airway reactivity and wall remodelling.

A. Brain infections G. Schroth; Berne/CH (gerhard.schroth@insel.ch)Although well protected by its bony surroundings and the dura mater, many types of microorganisms can infect the brain. Despite their differences, they can produce the same type of disease process. Therefore, neuroimaging reflects the host-parasite relationship -or the balance between the host defense system and the organism's ability to invade the central nervous system (CNS) -rather than the characteristics of the specific infecting agent. One of the major characteristics of CNS infection and non-infectious inflammation is the increase in water content (gray matter: 80 to 90%, white matter: 70 to 85%), which can be visualized as a decrease of density on the CT (about 5 Hounsfield units) and an increase of signal intensity on T2 weighted MR imaging, due to prolongation of the T2 relaxation time, whereas T1 prolongation leads to a decrease of signal intensity on T1 weighted images. In white matter these changes in relaxation times are accentuated, because the amount of protein-lipid decreases as the myelin is destroyed. Some brain infections are more characterized by a cytotoxic edema and disorganisation/demyelination of white matter tracts (e.g. PML, SSPE, Herpes simplex encephalitis) which can be best detected by diffusion weighted (MR) imaging (DWI) and/or diffusion tensor imaging (DTI). Corresponding to the neuropathological description of spongiform encephalopathy, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is characterized by small intra-extracellular cystic necrosis, leading to a restriction of water and a signal increase on DWI.The major pathological change in other CNS infections, e.g. early cerbritis and brain abscess, is the defect of the blood-brain-barrier, which can be detected by intravenously administering substances that normally do not cross the intact BBB. Cranial meninges may be involved in various pathological processes leading to infectious, carcinomatous, chemical/reactive, and inflammatory meningitis. Infection is a common cause of meningeal disease and may be caused by any of the common infectious agents including bacteria, fungi, viruses and granulomatous agents depending on the age of the patient and the status of their immune system. Imaging modalities are not employed for initial diagnosis of meningitis. The imaging features of meningitis are usually nonspecific and in most cases diagnosis relies on the history, and other clinical and laboratory findings, most importantly CSF analysis. MR imaging is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosis and the monitoring of treatment. Contrast is mandatory and has improved the sensitivity and specificity particularly in the early phase. Unenhanced MR examinations of patients with uncomplicated meningitis may be unremarkable. Postcontrast images demonstrate the abnormal meningeal enhancement and thickening. Obliteration and contrast enhancement of subarachnoid space are differentiating findings of advanced meningitis. Involvement of basal cisterns is a pathognomic sign of granulomatous meningitis, including tuberculous leptomeningitis, fungal and sarcoid meningitis. CSF locations, loss of outline of the spinal cord, thickened and clumped nerve roots, adhesions of spinal cord and roots to the thecal sac are the findings of spinal meningitis. Imaging has a major role to demonstrate and to diagnose the development of complications, including infarction, cerebritis, abscess, subdural empyema or effusion, hydrocephalus, ventriculitis, and myelitis. The introduction of diffusion-weighted imaging, FLAIR, magnetization transfer and magnetic resonance spectroscopy has led to a better understanding. Learning Objectives:1. To learn about the etiology of meningeal infections. Clinical manifestations of the infections of the spine and spinal canal are often protean and non specific. Plain films are usually negative in the early stages of the disease and CT and MR imaging allow both earlier diagnosis and greater specificity. Spinal dura mater is a rather efficient anatomical barrier, and extension of infections processes from extra to intradural space or vice versa is uncommon. Spondylitis is more common in adult and discitis is more common in childhood. Routes of contamination include: 1) Hematogeneous spread (mainly from urinary infection). 2) Contiguous spread, from adjacent suppurative focus.3) Direct contamination, traumatic or iatrogenic. Bone scanning (99mTc -HMDP) is more sensitive than plain films but non specific. CT still represents a good screening method. Disc hypodensity is an early sign of disc infection and spondylodiscitis; cortical endplate erosions are better demonstrated on CT than on MR imaging. MR imaging is the imaging modality of choice. STIR and T2WI with fat saturation are more sensitive for bone marrow oedema and epidural involvement. Post Gd T1WI with fat saturation better delineates the extent of epidural and paraspinal involvement. Epidural infection is commonly associated with vertebral osteomyelitis. In pyogenic spondylitis, Staphylococcus aureus is the most common pathogen (50% of cases). Tuberculous spondylitis has a rising incidence in the past two decades. Differential diagnoses of spondylitis include degenerative spondylosis, spinal metastases, and spondylarthropathies. Septic facet arthritis is rare (4%), most common in the lumbar spine and complicated by epidural abscess in 25% of cases. Percutaneous vertebral/abscess biopsy under CT guidance allows bacterial examination and appropriate treatment. MR imaging is the examination of choice for the follow-up of patients treated with antibiotics. Physiologic and pathologic calcifications in the face and neck usually do not play a major role during the evaluation and diagnosis of diseases in the face and neck. However, in certain circumstances, detection and correct interpretation of head and neck calcifications can be extremely helpful to find the correct diagnosis e.g. in retinoblastoma, fungal sinusitis, or labyrinthitis. Therefore, this course gives a systematic presentation of physiologic and pathologic calcifications in the face and neck and highlights those calcifications you do not want to miss. Learning Objectives: 1. To be aware of physiologic and pathologic processes leading to calcification in the face and neck. 2. To be able to recognise physiologic forms of calcification and distinguish these from pathological lesions. 3. To be able to recognise pathological forms of calcification and to relate these to differential diagnosis and therapeutic implications.Before starting endoscopic sinus surgery procedures the surgeon wants to have detailed information of the sinonasal anatomy to prevent major complications. Multislice, non contrast enhanced CT is the preferred technique to depict the paranasal sinuses. Thin axial slices provide high quality coronal and sagittal reconstructions.Radiologists should be familiar with normal variants which may lead to potential complications, such as hypoplasia of one or more paranasal sinuses, Onodi cells, asymmetry of the ethmoid roof and postoperative changes from previous operations. Extension of disease into adjacent compartments should be recognized including the pterygopalatine fossa (PPF), the anterior and central skull base, and orbit. On the other hand, sinonasal disease may result from extranasal disease of odontogenic, skull base or orbital origin. The most common pathologies in the nose and paranasal sinuses are polyposis and chronic sinusitis. Bilateral soft tissue masses are seen, sometimes accompanied by osseous thickening, so-called osteitis. Acute inflammatory disease often is treated without imaging. Only when involvement of the orbit or the cranium is suspected, is CT with intravenous contrast injection indicated to evaluate intraorbital extension and this finding necessitates acute surgical intervention.In immunocompromised patients the possibility of fungal disease should be considered in the cases of bone destruction and extension into the retromaxillary space, the PPF or the skull base.A unilateral mass within one paranasal sinus should arouse suspicion of a tumour, benign or malignant. An antrochoanal polyp may present in this way, but malignant tumour may as well. MR imaging has additional value for evaluating these tumours. It is the anatomic complexity of the soft tissues of the neck and their relations that creates interpretation difficulties when imaging these structures. But, most lesions in this area can be seen or are palpable. Data from clinical history and physical examination should come to the knowledge of the radiologist before imaging with CT or MR. The same applies to endoscopy, needle aspiration or even ultrasound when placed before CT or MR. If we know well were is the problem, the doubt or what lesion to stage, pitfalls are minimized, so are the difficulties and disadvantages of imaging cervical soft tissues "in blind". Of course, to image this area a solid knowledge of the anatomy, variations and pathology are mandatory, as it is a good connection with the related specialties like ENT, neck surgeons and radiotherapy. Daily practice and working together in a team with clinicians and surgeons are the top clues that help to understand imaging and give the best information for the best patient care. Complications with considerable clinical significance: Reported one-month mortality rate is from 0% to 5%; the metaanalysis of 24 articles performed by Leertower indicates a one-month mortality rate below 1%. Secondary nephrectomy either surgical or by embolization was necessary in less than 1%. Surgical salvage operation was performed in 2.5% in early nineties, but in later reported metaanalysis it was less than 1% (the lower incidence of rescue surgery is most probably due to treatment of occlusive renal artery dissection by stent implantation).Complications with minor clinical significance: Usually minor groin bleeding/haematoma, minor to mild allergo-toxic reaction. The incidence varies from 0%-21%. Technical complications: Events, occurring during procedure with clinical consequence, but increasing procedural time/cost (stent misplacement, balloon rupture, dissection requiring additional stent). They could sometimes (but rarely) have resulted in complications of clinical significance. The incidence is reported from 0% to 83%, but the true average incidence is unknown, as some authors do not report these complications at all.

The mean incidence of complications after PTRA is 5%-20%. The majority of them are not life threatening and do not result in loss of renal function, but they are dependant on patient selection and operator's experience. Even if the incidence of complications is low and the loss of life directly related to PTRA is rare, each case should be evaluated individually and the anticipated procedure benefit must outweigh the risks involved. The studies by Goldblatt in the 1930s have shown that renal artery stenosis (RAS) is the underlying cause of renovascular hypertension (RVH). RAS culminating in RVH is the most frequent cause of secondary hypertension with an estimated prevalence of 3-5% in the general population of hypertensive patients. Despite this low percentage, detection of RAS is important because it is a potentially curable cause of hypertension. In the majority of cases RVH is caused by either atherosclerotic RAS or fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD). Atherosclerosis accounts for 70-90 percent of cases of RAS and usually involves the ostium and proximal third of the renal artery. Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) is a collection of vascular diseases that affects the intima, media and adventitia and is responsible for 10-30 percent of cases of RAS. Intra-arterial digital subtraction angiography (IA-DSA) is traditionally regarded as the definitive test to diagnose RAS. However, both the invasive nature of IA-DSA and the difficulty in assessing the pathophysiological significance of stenotic lesions have encouraged the search for non-or minimally invasive diagnostic tests. In addition, IA-DSA is by no means a perfect test for the detection of RAS as it is subject to substantial interobserver variation.With the introduction of contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance angiography (CE-MRA), multidetector row computed tomographic angiography (MD-CTA) and duplex ultrasonography, alternatives for IA-DSA are emerging. An overview of these techniques with their merits and shortcomings will be discussed. Diagnostic algorithms for the diagnosis of RAS will be evaluated in the context of these and other diagnostic tests. Indications for renal artery angioplasty still remain controversial, even 28 years after the first renal angioplasty done by Grüntzig. It is mainly due to the lack of large, comparative studies and also due to the complexity of the physiopathology of the kidney and impairment of the cardiovascular system. However, there are some proven indications where renal angioplasty should be done such as refractory hypertension, rapid renal failure, flash pulmonary oedema, indication for some medicine, … The talk will focus first in the approach to the physiology of the kidney and physiopathology of renal artery stenosis. Then proven indications will be analysed with examples and remaining indications will be discussed. New indications will be also discussed such as pectoris angina. Renal artery stenosis should also be considered as a cardiovascular risk marker. The mortality rate of this population is very high, maybe more than patients with lower limb disease. Associated treatment of atherosclerosis should always occur to prevent cardiovascular events. Aortic dissection (AD) is the most emergent acute disease of the thoracic aorta. The mortality rate is up to 80% without treatment with a rate of 1-2% per hour after symptom onset for Stanford type A AD (ascending aorta). The first aim of a diagnostic strategy is to be highly efficient to prove the AD and to localise it. This is currently well done with transoesophageal echocardiography or CT scan. Type A AD will be operated on while type B is medically treated. Since the development of endovascular treatments of AD complications (i.e. malperfusion syndromes, aortic ruptures), another role of imaging tools will be a complete investigation of the aorta and its collaterals. To date, CT scan is the best imaging technique for doing that and thus, the radiologist will play a main role in the investigation of the dissected aorta. He must establish the diagnosis and consequently order a surgical repair if needed, look for signs of imminent rupture, say whether or not there is a risk of collateral ischemia and thus endovascular treatment to be initiated. The radiologist must also know the spectrum of akin thoracic aortic diseases that are sometimes merged with AD, such as intramural haematomas, ruptured aneurysms and penetrating aortic ulcers. These different faces of acute medical aortic diseases are brought together under the concept of acute aortic syndrome. This presentation will expose these different points of the imaging of dissection and acute aortic syndromes. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) has long been considered as the gold standard in the evaluation of the abdominal arteries. Nevertheless, it remains an invasive method carrying the risk of complications especially in the older population. CT angiography (CTA) and MR angiography (MRA) are considered the best noninvasive tests for the evaluation of the renal and visceral arteries and are gradually replacing DSA in this field. However, there is still some concern that CTA or MRA may overlook mild or distal abnormalities due to their relatively low spatial resolution. The dramatic recent developments of multidetector CT offer sub-millimeter resolution which is especially important considering the size and the course of the renal and visceral arteries. Still, new challenges appeared such as the adequate arterial opacification and the appearance of image noise. Traditional MRA examinations have been almost completely displaced by contrast enhanced techniques. By incorporating the new parallel acquisition techniques, MRA of the renal arteries is now feasible with isotropic sub-millimeter resolution. New tests such as MR renography can be combined with MRA providing information about the functional significance of stenoses. This review discusses the anatomy and the clinical significance of renal and visceral artery variants. It provides an overview of the indications and limitations of CTA and MRA in several clinical settings. It critically discusses the existing discrepancies between different studies that affect the widespread application of renal and visceral CTA and MRA. MRA and CTA are increasingly used for imaging peripheral arterial occlusive disease, they are non-invasive and MRA also avoids ionising radiation and contrast nephrotoxicity. Claudication and critical lower limb ischaemia (CLLI) are usually clinically distinct as are the techniques for their imaging. In claudication the problem lies in larger vessels in the pelvis/thighs whereas in CLLI the major problem usually lies in the crural vessels with or without remediable aortoiliac/ femoral disease. Hence in CLLI detail of the tibial vasculature is crucial yet this requires both high spatial resolution and speed as in CLLI, rapid arteriovenous shunting leads to obscuration of vessels through venous overlay. Fluoroscopy is still an important diagnostic procedure and represents about 10% of childhood radiographic exposures, whereby uroradiologic and gastroenterologic examinations dominate in frequency. In a Europe-wide survey on micturition cystourethrography (MCU) the radiation exposure varied by a factor of 1:500 depending on examination protocol and equipment technology. Pulsed digital fluoroscopy equipment, modern digital image management and specially adapted fluoroscopic automatic exposure control have been available for many years. The selection of the lowest possible system dose, use of high filtration, selective use of a grid and the right choice of image acquisition can considerably reduce the radiation exposure. In addition, an effective optimisation strategy for paediatric fluoroscopy requires standardisation of examination protocols, which will be shown in the example of MCU. As an example for gastroenterological procedures, the use of digital video loops for examining the swallowing act as part of a standardized protocol will be discussed. The potential for dosimetry and its interpretation will also be presented. All these measures contribute to truly optimised fluoroscopy in paediatrics. Image digitization and networking are entering the radiology departments and hospitals in a revolutionary way. Distances are shrinking, information flows broader and faster. With the aging and the substitution of radiological equipment a steadily growing number of hospitals opt for digital radiography and PACS. This refresher course is aimed at radiologists who are planning to digitize their department or who are facing certain questions or problems after having done so. Emphasis will be on pediatric imaging aspects like dose effectiveness and speed and quality of processing. It points out the main imaging modalities for plain X-ray imaging in pediatric radiology. In the center of the course will be the use of the flat panel technology. This necessarily includes CR systems which will be compared to DR. We will also focus on the use of standard and dual read CR systems as an alternative or supplement to DR. Another important issue will be the technical implications of optimizing the whole imaging-chain up to the final image and to keep up constant quality. The workflow changes substantially concerning internal organization and image distribution in a DR and digital imaging working field. Switching from plain film to digital means a transition to a whole new imaging concept -and it also means a lot of work and dedication to reach this aim. Radiation protection plays an increasing role in CT imaging. In particular, CT in young patients requires special attention to this matter. Besides limiting indications for CT to clinical questions that cannot be answered by ultrasound or MRI, several parameters should be considered as potential means for radiation reduction: kV, mAs, dose modulation modes. Other parameters such as beam filters, number of slices (4-slice, 16-slice, 64-slice CT), reconstruction filters, and patient positioning influence the radiation level as well. Several age-and body weightrelated protocol suggestions have been published and will be reviewed, including recommendations for the amount of intravenous contrast material, speed and site of injection, scanner and post-processing settings. Special focus will be set on lung disease patterns i.e. in sequestration syndrome including congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM), intra-and extralobar lung sequestration (ILS, ELS), congenital lobar emphysema (CLE), and bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD). Clinical audits were introduced by the European Union in the Medical Exposure Directive (MED) in 1997. According to the MED directive, clinical audits are a systematic examination or review of medical radiological procedures which seek to improve the quality of patient care. The objective is to avoid unnecessary or excessive exposure to radiation and to improve the quality and effectiveness of medical use of radiation. Finland has been among the first countries to start clinical audits in Europe. According to the Finnish legislation clinical audits have to be carried out every five years in clinics where radiation is used for medical purposes. Clinical audits cover the whole radiological procedure. The auditors monitor agreed standards of good medical practise, legal requirements and safety aspects. Clinical audits are an evaluation of functions and documentation, and concentrate on work of health care professionals, who should be appropriately educated. The auditors produce an independent assessment, report on the findings and make recommendations. The clinic decides which actions it will take based on the recommendations of the clinical audit. Experiences on the first 104 clinical audits in Finland are summarized in a report which shows how the audits have started and the recommendations given to the X-ray departments. Reduction of ionising radiation is the most significant benefit of clinical audits. Clinical audits help to develop the quality system which suggests a mechanism to prevent mistakes. The benefits of clinical audit will be discussed in detail in the presentation. As the principal route whereby most breast carcinomas spread to distant tissues is via the lymphatics, the determination of nodal invasion is of particular importance.The sentinel node hypothesis is based on the fact that sentinel nodes are the first nodes draining a tumor and that their histological status predicts the status of the regional lymphatic basin. Sentinel node biopsy has a success rate of 88%, a sensitivity of 93% and an accuracy of 97%. Using sentinel node biopsy, costs and morbidity of an axillary lymph node dissection can be avoided in nodal negative patients. Lymphoscintigraphy and blue dye injection represent the current gold standard. Technical parameters for sentinel node biopsy vary. Studies differ with respect to many parameters, including the labelling agent (radioisotope, blue dye or both) used for preoperative lymphatic mapping, the volume and site (peritumoral, intradermal, periareolar or intratumoral) of injection, and the interval between injection and surgery. Moreover, recently published studies show serious potentials for PET, MR and even 3-dimensional multidetector-row computed tomography lymphography. Contrast agents allow perfusional studies that increase the sensitivity for small nodal metastases and allow useful monitoring in locally advanced breast cancer. Molecular imaging with optical and near infrared probes may be performed in the near future. Magnetic resonance imaging is one of the very few imaging techniques that require thorough understanding of the underlying physical principles. Without knowledge of these basics interpretation of images is extremely difficult or almost impossible. However, MR physics is complex and therefore difficult to understand for physicians. An expert panel of MR physicists will introduce basic principles of MR physics in a way that beginners but also more advanced users can get a comprehensive insight into the creation of an MR image. Learning Objective: 1. To learn why understanding of MR physics is important for radiologists.

Fourier transform: How does it work and how we use it O. Speck; Freiburg/DE (oliver.speck@uniklinik-freiburg.de)The Fourier transform is the essential mathematical tool that allows reconstruction of the recorded MR signals into images. However, knowledge and intuition about the Fourier transformation (FT) are often limited among MR users.With simple examples and analogies the FT will be introduced. The acquisition of MR raw data and the reconstruction process are closely related to the concept of kspace. This concept allows to describe many aspects of MR imaging in an intuitive way without the need for exact mathematical formulations of the problem. Thus, the conceptual similarity between read and phase encoding can be explained and the common reconstruction by means of two-dimensional FT becomes clear. Many of the MR imaging properties are governed by the properties of the FT. Image field of view, resolution, fold-over, and motion artifacts are a consequence of the discrete data sampling in k-space and the reconstruction using FT. The processes of image encoding, acquisition and reconstruction will be described and simple, advanced and surprising examples of the role of the FT in MR imaging will be presented.

The origin of contrast on anatomical MR J. Bittoun; Le Kremlin-Bicêtre/FR (jacques.bittoun@cierm.u-psud.fr)The purpose of this lecture is to introduce the basic physical phenomena driving T1 and T2 values in normal and pathologic tissues. In the presence of a magnetic field Bo, spins of hydrogen nuclei can only adopt two orientations: parallel or antiparallel. Moreover, they are not perfectly aligned but form a small angle with the magnetic field. At equilibrium, since parallel spins are a majority and since there is no preferred orientation in the transverse plane, the macroscopic magnetization in each voxel is parallel to the magnetic field. An RF pulse at resonance has 2 effects: 1) transition of spins from the parallel to the anti-parallel level, 2) relative phasing of spins in the transverse plane. These 2 effects flip the magnetisation from the Bo direction. The return towards equilibrium is similarly the result of 2 phenomena: 1) a return to the initial proportion of spins on the two levels by stimulated transition, resulting in a recovery of the longitudinal magnetization, with a characteristic time T1; 2) spin dephasing due to field heterogeneity at the molecular scale resulting in a decrease of the transverse magnetization with a characteristic time T2. Both phenomena are caused by molecular magnetic interactions depending on molecular mobility: the most mobile molecules have the longest T1 and T2. This explains why fatty tissues have the shortest relaxation times whereas water has the longest ones. Furthermore, pathologic tissues with increased water mobility (edema, water of malignant cells…) have longer T1 and T2 values.

Going faster: A map in the jungle of gradient echoes and update on parallel imaging K. Scheffler; Basle/CH Steady state free precession: A steady state can only be reached for sequences with a: 1) fixed TR,2) constant flip angle, and 3) constant dephasing within TR. From point 3 it can be deduced that the phase encoding gradient, which changes from excitation to excitation has to be refocused. Sequences with non-refocused phase encode gradients do not establish a steady state. The steady state magnetization does not depend on the chosen gradient waveform that is switched between the excitation pulses. The steady state magnetization generated just before and after the excitation pulse (sometimes called S+ and S-, respectively) is thus identical for all types of gradient echo sequences. The type of the read-out gradient selects whether the S+ or the S-magnetization (or both) is used for imaging. A conventional bipolar read-out gradient selects the S + signal (refocused FLASH, GRASS, FAST, sometimes FISP, FFE), whereas the time reversed gradient waveform selects the S-signal (PSIF, CE-FAST, CE-FFE). Basics of Parallel Imaging-Parallel imaging exploits the difference in sensitivities between individual coil elements in a receive array to reduce the number of gradient encoding steps required for imaging. Sodickson, et al. proposed a method known as SiMultaneous Acquisition of Spatial Harmonics (SMASH) which is a k-space implementation of parallel MR imaging. Pruessmann et al. presented a general formulation and performance analysis of the image domain sensitivity encoding method (SENSE). Learning Objectives:1. To learn how can we optimise visualization in rapid imaging. 2. To understand how parallel imaging works. 3. To learn how to find analogies among the large number of used acronyms for image sequences.
